(1) Are they mutation forms of the malignant tertian parasite?

(2) Are they quinine-resistant forms of the malignant tertian para-
site?

(3) Are they a separate species of parasite which are relatively
quinine-resistant?
(1) These parasites are known to be of two different species.

(2) The short interval relapses after quinine treatment, according
to this view, would be more likely to be due to benign tertian forms and
the long interval relapses (8 to 14 weeks after treatment) would more
likely be due to malignant tertian forms, but this is not so (see Sec-
tion 11, Tables 11 and 111). These were all cases on tonic treatment
and the quinine effect should have worn off after cessation of treatment.

(3) Benign tertian parasites are seen in persons who have never
had quinine treatment.
Section IV--What Constitues A Cure.

---------- THE NATURE OF CURES IN MALARIA, by H. W. Acton.
Major. I. M. S.
Conclusions.
(1) Cures in malaria occur in the following ways:--

(A) Natural cures by a gradual conversion of the whole of
the asexual cycle into gametocytes. The gametocytes in turn dying as
the result of senility or being destroyed by the splenic cells.

(B) Artificial cures by the rapid destruction of the asex-
ual cycle by quinine or other alkaloids of cinchona bark.

(2) The production of cure may be considered to be brought about
in three phases--

(A) Immediate or relative cure is the immediate effect pro-
duced by destroying the greater part of the asexual cycle and is shown

B21
shown
-2-
by the disappearance of fever and the asexual forms from the peripheral
blood.

(B) Partial cure or relapse due to the incomplete destruction
of the asexual cycle by quinine or by excessive gametocyte formation, the
asexual parasites reappear and cause fever.

(C) Complete cure or sterilisation is the complete destruction
of the asexual cycle by quinine or by gametocyte formation and leads to a
permanent cure.

(3) Relative cures of particular types of treatment should always
be tested experimentally as the rapid abatement of fever is important to
the patient. The intravenous treatment gives the best relative cure.
(4) Partial cures or relapses--

(A) During treatment, are due to the maladministration of
quinine (i. e., by intermittent dosage, and the patient avoiding treat-
ment), or to non-absorption. These faults are all rectifiable.

(B) After treatment, relapses are due to the failure of the
drug to destroy the whole of the asexual cycle and are probably caused
by one of the following factors:--

Insufficiency of treatment, this is dependent on the number of
parasites present and the rate of destruction by quinine. The destruct-
ion may be considered to be a fractional process with each new cycle.

Inaccessibility of the drug to destroy the young forms, as schizo-
gony may occur in areas where these alkaloids are not sufficiently con-
centrated.

(5) Complete cure or sterilisation is brought about by the acces-
sibility of the alkaloid for the parasite, i. e., quinine for the malig-
nant tertian parasite. The concentration of the alkaloid must be suf-
ficient to destroy young broods and the site of multiplication must be
accessible to the action of the alkaloid. This destruction may be con-

CONDITIONS REQUIRED FOR AN EXPERIMENTAL TEST OF A CURE IN MALARIA.

(1) The full curative value of quinine and other alkaloids can on-
ly be properly estimated under conditions that preclude the possibiliti-
ties of reinfection occurring during treatment and observation.

(2) The observation period necessary to establish a cure in be-
nign tertian infections should not be under eight weeks so as to in-
clude 90 per cent of the relapses. The number of cases not relapsing dur-
ing this period are spoken of as “cures.”

(3) The relapses that occur after eight weeks can roughly be es-
timated at 8% of the relapses that have occurred during the eight weeks'
observation, the sum of these relapses we call “the total relapse rate.”

(4) 'The total estimated cures' will be the total population un-
der treatment, minus the total relapse rate.

(5) Before a particular treatment can be recommended, the error
of chance distribution should be excluded by repeating the test.

DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT OF B. T. AND M. T., FEVERS. (Section V)
The Effect of Quinine on Benign Tertian Infection.
by
Major P. M. Rennie, I. M. S.
Major H. W. Acton, I. M. S.
Dagmar F. Curjel, M. D., W. M. S.,
attached R. A. M. C.
Asst. Surg. J. O. Dewey, I. M. D.
Conclusion.

(1) The immediate cure of benign tertian fever by quinine is soon-
est effected by the intravenous method, but by whatever method quinine
is given, the parasites in benign tertian infection disappear from the

from the
-4-
peripheral blood in one to four days.

(2) By whatever method quinine is given, approximately 25 to 30
per cent of cases are cured by a single course.

(3) Of the various methods of quinine administration the oral is
the most practical for routine use, and gives as good results as the
others.

(4) The continuous oral administration is better than the inter-
mittent.

(5) The percentage of cures resulting from a three weeks' course
and from an eight weeks' course is about the same.

(6) The difference between a four months' course (Ross and Thomson) and
the short continuous oral course is small, and probably two short courses
would give a better cure percentage than one long course.
Section VI.

The Effect of Repeated Courses of Quinine on the Benign and Malignant
Tertian Parasites.
H. W. Acton, Dagmar F. Curjel and J. O. Dewey.
Conclusions.

(1) In malignant tertian infections, with a month's course of qui-
nine treatment, a cure rate of over 90 per cent is obtained when the pa-
tient is removed from the chance of reinfection. Under these circum-
stances, three courses of quinine would cure all cases of infection due
to this parasite.

(2) In benign tertian infections, with every two months' course of
quinine treatment, about 25 to 30 per cent of the cases are cured whether
by a single or repeated courses. We have observed this effect with five
consecutive courses. Under such conditions, 16 courses of quinine would
be required to cure every case in a large series of men.

C1
B21 men.

(3) Two short courses of three weeks' continuous treatment is as ef-
fective as long four months' course, and gives as large a number of ef-
fective men in a shorter space of time besides saving money in quinine.

(4) The high cure rate in malignant tertian infections, i. e., 90%,
is dependent on the hign destructive rate of quinine on the young asex-
ual parasite coupled with the easy accessibility of this drug to the
parasitic breeding grounds, which are in the portal area. A cure is as-
sured every time, provided the treatment is carried over eight to ten cy-
cles (21 to 30 days).

(5) The low cure rate in benign tertian infections, i. e., 25 to
30 per cent, is dependent not on the low destructive rate of quinine on
the asexual parasites, but on the fact that schizogony occurs through-
out the body and is not specially restricted to the portal area. Quinine,
therefore, does not gain an easy access to these young forms, and the cure
or complete destruction is dependent on pure chance.
